Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will address the presence of parameter-tampering security holes in web applications. Current market tools do not appear to have the capabilities to detect these security holes in an automatic fashion. Parameter tampering vulnerabilities are rampant in commercial as well as open source web applications. Further, it has been shown that these vulnerabilities could be exploited by malicious actors to make financial gains.

It is important to note that the proposed solution is unique in the sense that it offers not only to detect the web security, but also to fix the issue by correcting the code. If successfully deployed, this effort holds the promise of addressing an emerging security threat in a manner that is both robust and cost-effective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project was to test the commercial viability of web security technology that was developed by researchers in the University of Illinois at Chicago. Specifically, this project  tested the commercial viability of  security  vulnerability detection technology in web applications. It is important to note that the technology furthered in this project is unique in the sense that it offers not only to detect vulnerabilities, but also  fix the issue by suggesting patches.

The project enabled several technology transfer activities that include :
(1) Attended an I-Corps workshop at the University of Michigan and participated in the workshop activities. These include making presentations on the technology every week through Internet conference, collecting feedback. Along with that, a blog was maintained that highlighted the interactions with potential customers. 
(2) Delivered presentations about the value propositions behind the technology to a group of academics, entrepreneurs and investors.
(3) Collected feedback from such interactions and improved the tool to make it more attractive from a technology standpoint. A new port of the tool was developed to broaden its reach. 


In addition, this project furthered human resource development including: (1) training of the PI and his team in technology transfer activities and (2) research training of graduate students in designing and implementing software tools.  

 

 


Last Modified: 03/11/2014
Modified by: V. N. Venkatakrishnan
